nameEntry.part: Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse

biogHist.abstract:
On 12 November 2012, the Prime Minister Julia Gillard announced the creation of a national Royal Commission into institutional responses to instances of child sexual abuse. A website has been set up to give information about the Royal Commission, which will:
Inquire into how institutions with a responsibility for children have managed and responded to allegations and instances of child sexual abuse
Investigate where systems have failed to protect children, and
Make recommendations on how to improve laws, policies and practices to prevent and better respond to child sexual abuse in institutions
The Commissioners are to look at any private, public or non-government organisation that is, or was in the past, involved with children (including government agencies, schools, sporting clubs, orphanages, foster care, and religious organisations) if they believe an organisation is responsible for the abuse or for not responding appropriately, regardless of where or when the abuse took place.

archref.abstract: 'Joint Statement from the Christian Brothers (Oceania Province) and Edmund Rice Education Australia (EREA) in relation to the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse' offers an apology and provides information about mandatory reporting, support and redress services for people who were abused in schools and institutions run by the Christian Brothers in Australia. The statement was issued prior to the first sitting of the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse.
